summary: This is a joint letter from the prosecution and defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case (20 Cr. 330) to Judge Alison J. Nathan. It addresses logistical procedures for protecting witness identities at the upcoming trial, including proposed nomenclature for witnesses, voir dire procedures, jury instructions, and handling of sealed exhibits. The defense largely accepts the government's proposals.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The letter is addressed to her, and she issues orders and rulings on procedural matters related to witness protection.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). The document pertains to the procedures for her trial.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted the government's position in the letter.

persons.name: Judge Garaufis
persons.context: Judge in the unrelated United States v. Raniere case, whose jury instruction on witness anonymity is cited as a model by the government.

persons.name: Ms. Penza
persons.context: Appears in the transcript excerpt, representing the government during a court proceeding, discussing witness list logistics.

persons.name: Mr. Agnifilo
persons.context: Appears in the transcript excerpt, representing the defense, objecting to the proposed jury instruction.

persons.name: Denise Parisi
persons.context: The court reporter for the transcribed proceedings included in the document.

connections.description: Mr. Agnifilo is acting as defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, objecting to procedures on her behalf.
Both are prosecutors for the U.S. Attorney's Office in the Southern District of New York working on the Maxwell case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.
They represent opposing sides (prosecution and defense) in the courtroom, as shown in their exchange during the transcript.

events.title: Pretrial Conference
events.description: A pretrial conference was held where Judge Nathan directed the parties to file a joint letter regarding protections for witness identities at the upcoming Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Start
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin on this date.

events.title: Court Denies Motion for Mistrial
events.description: During a proceeding (transcript included), the defense moved for a mistrial, which Judge Nathan denied, opting instead to issue a curative jury instruction regarding witness anonymity.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio!. Mono Building, One Saint Andrew's Plana, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The prosecution and defense agreed on procedures to protect the identities of victims and witnesses at Ghislaine Maxwell's trial, including using pseudonyms or first names only.
Judge Nathan denied a defense motion for a mistrial related to witness naming issues, deciding a jury instruction would suffice.
The trial was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.
The government cited procedures from the unrelated United States v. Raniere case as a model for witness anonymity instructions.
The document reveals significant efforts to balance a public trial with protecting victim privacy, including using sealed juror lists and exhibit binders.
